SourceString: \"The other centaurs live by impulse alone, like Ixion, their forefather. I share their form, but not their blood. It is a lonely thing, to be unlike your kin. But I do not think they are lost yet...\"
\"Achilles, swift of foot, was swifter still in anger. Yet he held the lyre as gently as he did his mother’s hand. I taught him balance: that rage must be tempered, like iron in the forge.\"

\"A wound may close with time, but pain, when made immortal, does not obey time\'s laws. I have dressed the flesh of men and gods, and yet I cannot fully soothe my own. Nevertheless, I will not surrender.\"
\"Nemesis drained the lake seeking Titan Ichor. But what does she plan to use its power for? If the Olympians will not investigate, then I must.\"
\"Kronos! She wants to use the power of Ouranos\'s blood to raise Kronos! She wants to unweave the strands of these past millennia!\"

A translation from an ancient text with annotations and notes surrounding it:\r\n\r\n\"The one born with the gods\' mark, a half-moon on the right shoulder, if raised to godhood, will bring about Retribution\'s downfall.\"

\"I will begin to keep a record of my thoughts so as not to go mad. I have seen what time alone can do to the noblest of creatures. I will not falter, as Chiron never did, even in the end...\"\r\n\r\nA few short, confusing entries after this are filled in, but then the diary is abandoned.
\"Even a small piece has enough power to be dangerous! With enough... she <b>could</> raise Kronos...
\"Dear Electra,\r\n\r\nI hope Agave got this to you safely. I won\'t be able to visit the surface of the city like I promised. It\'s too dangerous right now. Tell the children that I...\"
\"My Brandbearers!\r\nAny human outside the city walls is a soldier! An enemy warrior to be defeated! Take their heads and earn glory in Ixion\'s name!\r\n- Skirion\"
\"Keep an eye out for any people trying to flee the city. Once the Brandbearers trample them, any valuables left on the bodies are ours.\"
\"Brother, you should have joined us at the warcamp! Skirion is fighting a <i>human</> and we\'re taking bets on whether he\'ll need to bring out his clubs infused with flame and ice.\"
\"The helm of Fridolinos, slayer of the Stone-Hooves, who won the Contest against the people of Tegea during the Crisis of Three Tribes.\"
\"The helm of Phaedo, who was insulted that Archon Evios did not invite the centaurs to his wedding. He slew the Archon\'s champion.\"
\"Hold back the rabble! Spend your lives defending the palace or I will give you a slower death than any mob ever could.\"

\"The king\'s tyranny must end. A kinslayer cannot be our ruler. But be wary. Ares is his father, and his size and strength are far greater than any mortal man\'s. Flames obey his commands. Be brave. Be quick.\"
The pit burns with tireless supernatural flames. Charred skeletons sizzle at the bottom, as they have for centuries.
A mutilated skeleton lies broken upon the wheel, flesh long rotted away. Such a death must have been incredibly painful.

The statue of Zeus is ancient, but fine craftsmanship can be seen beneath the dust. An inscription is carved into the stone:\r\n\r\n\"Great Zeus, I am a king down below as you are on high. Watch over me as I struggle to manage to unwashed masses, to bring them into the light of your worship.\"
\"Any who claim that I did not conquer the queen of the gods are to be broken upon the wheel. I will not have my accomplishments questioned by my own subjects.\"
Its palace guard uniform is faded, and its legs are shattered where chunks of ceiling fell on it in centuries past... something truly powerful must have broken in from above.
The leavings of animals butchered by centaurs--stinking offal and blade-scored bones.
Symbols are freshly carved into stone. Barely intelligible, but clearly exalting Ixion, the centaur forefather.
\"No, sub-standard wine simply will not do! King Ixion will want to send someone to the dungeons if any noble guests complain, and I\'ll ensure he knows exactly who is responsible.\"
Threads crumble like old papyrus at the edges, but the shape still holds: a ghost of cloth, curled in the dust, whispering of vanished steam and human touch.

Georgios,

The centaurs have become even more ruthless in recent months, so make sure to stay safe and keep on the roads.
I'm looking forward to seeing you again.

Love,
Elina

PS: 
Listen to Scratch's barking, you know he's always had a nose for danger.
Perfectly good food left in the dirt.
Someone took a single bite before tossing this on the ground.
Not a bit of mold or decay on this food.
Fresh food near fresh horse dung.
These rebel fighters sustained many wounds before dying.
The wood of the wagon and crates were splintered by force and left scattered.
Blood and hoofprints... leading somewhere up ahead.
Recent spilling of blood, and ritual markings around a sacrificial bowl...
The cracked remains of an ancient stele reads:  \r\n\r\n\"...pay homage to… warfare and strife. An enemy\'s bloo… collected in sacred bowls… fortified with Ares’s strength…\"
\"K,\r\nThe owl will deliver the egg at the agreed time.\r\nD\"
Many names of the dead are inscribed here, most faded and unreadable. But the first entry was carved deep and bold: \r\n\r\n\"Burrhus, one with his pack\"
The remnants of a message in the corpse\'s belongings:\r\n\r\n\"...rumor is... urrhus was buried with... and gold!\"
The inscription reads: \r\n\"Step lightly and precisely. Be aware of your surroundings.\" -- Burrhus
The sarcophagus is empty... Burrhus\'s remains must be elsewhere.
A clay tablet lays among some bones:\r\n\r\n\"Take my body from the lonely stone, and let me rest in the den. May the last of my wolves find another worthy hunter. -- Burrhus\"

Carved into the stone is a series of expanding circles surrounding a fire. The inscription reads: 

“Our old beliefs were wrong. We now understand the seven heavenly wanderers begin with the flames like <b>Helios</> and end with the furthest, like displaced <b>Kronos</>. 
In between, we have the swiftest wanderer, much like <b>Hermes</> himself, then the evening beauty of <b>Aphrodite</> who is followed by our very own <b>Gaia</>. 
Next is the wanderer covered in red like the sword of <b>Ares</>. 
And the mightiest wanderer stands just in front of his father–”. 

Whatever text followed was ruined long ago.
A braced holder for a flag or banner, but it is empty.
This is the banner under which Taros and his fighters made their final, valiant stand against the Brandbearers.

“I gift to you, dear goddess, the meek harvest of my remaining crops. 
My sheep, goats, and my finest swine are yours as well. 

I humbly ask only for your aid in returning Tegea and the surrounding lands to the control of the Archon. 

We suffer greatly under the hooves of these centaur protectors-turned-tyrants.”

"Is this a test of my devotion, my faith?
 
I sacrificed all of my possessions, but Eris has not stopped the centaurs yet. 

She is displeased with my offerings.
That must be it! 

There are only three things left I can offer her. May my gifts preserve Tegea. 

And may my wife and son find peace."
A sign on the door reads:\r\n \r\n“Seek permission from Leandros before entering, friend.”

“No one has had luck praying to the gods of Olympos. My prayers grow more desperate. Eris - the goddess of strife and discord - has surely had her fill with what has happened here in Tegea. 

There is a shrine nearby. I will honor her with anything I can, and she will see reason. She must! 

Eris will put an end to this war with the centaurs. She will save us, I know it.”

"We observe, in the night sky, wanderering lights like the gods, while standing on our very own Gaia. 
Kronos surrounded by a ring.
Ares is red like his sword after battle.
Mighty Zeus only dwarfed by the burning giant that is Helios. 
Hermes, so fast and small.
And a light in the evening and at dawn, with the beauty of Aphrodite."

This altar of the goddess of the harvest stands amid the withered grass and dried dirt. Offerings of food are scattered about. \r\n\r\nThe air is heavy with absence, as if something special was here once, but is now gone.
A hand-stitched peacock adorns a piece of cloth in this warrior\'s belongings. It must have been significant.
\"Turn Ares three times, but prepare for as many wars.\"
Fine lettering, but the note is in bad shape:\r\n\r\n\"Only priests may light flames. They should come to no harm.\"
\"Three flames will vanquish the mists of primordial Erebos, predecessor to Hades, and his minions.\"\r\n\r\n-- Priestess Agamede
Bits of words still remain around the bowl:\r\n\r\n“In memo… the silent sentinels, born… stone and storm. Only worth… worship here.”
An old, quickly-written note:\r\n\r\n“Only… strong… worthy…”
“Like wind, you move,\r\nOr like wood, you burn.\"

“This will not be a mission without peril, but those Spartans risked everything for us. The least we can do as priests is help their souls find rest. 

Burn this incense near where they fell, and all shall be made right.
– Priest Dares”
“Our old beliefs were wrong. We now understand the seven heavenly wanderers begin with the flames like <b>Helios</> and end with the furthest, like displaced <b>Kronos</>.\"

\"In between, we have the Keeper of the Flocks himself, then the evening beauty who is followed by our very own <b>Gaia</>. \r\nNext is the wanderer of war. \r\nAnd the mightiest wanderer stands just in front of his crooked-counseling father–”.
\"His pack will forever mourn his passing, and keep watch over Burrhus eternally.\"

Rough chisel markings around the edges, but the inscription is mostly preserved:\r\n\r\n\"Bury me beside the crystal. Bury me with my legions. I know not what comes next, but will meet it with an army.\"
The dented bronze depicts a scene of many workers preparing a massive room or tomb for an important figure.
Minimal armor and far from other humans. A scout who met his end with these skeletons and boarmen.

"In honor of the King of Five Kings, from your humble kingdoms. 

To our wanax. 
To our warrior king.
To our brave lion."

A discarded ancient scroll, hardly legible:

"... of Five Kings, my wanax, 

Though... undeserving of your audience, as... advisor of state, I throw myself... mercy, and humbly request ending the work on your incredibly deserved tomb. 

The constant storms and fires... worsening. Immortality may have been too much to seek, let alone... treasured of tombs and crystal.

Your legion remains loyal... I beg of you to let them carry you... distant, somewhere safer. 

Your eternal..."
An old dagger, with a century\'s worth of rust, rests between the ribs.

An inscription from Tegea's infamous thief reads:

"First, follow all four suns of Tegea. Press the left panel for each illumination.

Then find three statuesque brothers, with their metal helms, who watch over Tegea. Use the panel on the right to name them."

"Count what the heavens above in their glory have granted
Number of Suns in Tegea are how many times you should turn left
Pillars of blue that uphold the sky count the times you have to turn right
Turn them in order, and treasures of victories of my past are yours."

"Clever the mortal who follows the fox through the streets of the city, 
Finding the pathway I wove from the laughter and riddles of Hermes. 

Long was I hidden, unseen by the watch and the sleepless immortals; 
Now you have taken the prey that no hunter had ever imagined. 

Claim it, O seeker, but know that the trickster is smiling upon you—
Gold is a gift, yet the game is the joy of Autolycus’ cunning."

A few scrolls are tucked away under the pot. 

"Few venture out this far, and I hope it stays like this forever. The light on the lake's waves are like a thousand sparkling jewels, just for me. Well, for me and Pegaea. 

No one believes that I saw her once - the naiad of this lake - just basking on a rock in all her splendor. But I did, I swear! They say she's a thousand years old, but she looked a year or two younger than me.

Maybe that's why I row out here each week. To sit on these stone walls, dangle my feet in the cool blue of the lake, and hope for another glance at her wondrous beauty..."

The other scrolls are a mix of romantic gestures and bawdy bits of remembered dreams.
This small offering, a statue of a dancing naiad, is half-buried and fully forgotten.

A wax tablet with markings lay among the ruins of the ship:\r\n\r\n\"Tonight, in honor of years of our love, I\'ve borrowed my father\'s boat. Prepare for wine, a wonderful sunset, and a feast grilled right on the deck.\"
Inside the sealed amphora is a scroll:\r\n\r\n\"I cast this prayer to you, spirit of the lake, and encourage you to take the lives of the fisherman, Bacis, and his sons. End his line of wickedness.\"
The gilded doors remain firmly shut, blocking access out of Hephaistos\'s domain into Olympos proper.
Supernatural flames radiate power that makes your skin tingle and your hair stand on end.

The words on the prayer scroll are faded by time and weather, but a fragment remains legible.:\r\n\r\n\"...Torchbearer! We beg your mercy! Answer us! Forgive us for our theft, allow our people to pass on to the underworld, and we will exalt your name through the ages! Your curse means the end of our...\"
The weathered bronze gates are closed fast, blocking access in or out of the city.
